Description.Content: Provides support for 'menu' resources; xml files that define the structure of application menus (such as those triggered through the Action Bar).
This must be the root node. Contains 'item' and/or 'group' elements.
Defines the XML namespace, which must be 'http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android'.
A menu item. May contain a 'menu' element (for a Sub Menu). Must be a child of a 'menu' or 'group' element.
A unique resource ID. To create a new resource ID for this item, use the form: '@+id/name'. The plus symbol indicates that this should be created as a new ID.
The menu title as a string resource or raw string.
A condensed title as a string resource or a raw string. This title is used for situations in which the normal title is too long.
An image to be used as the menu item icon.

The method to call when this menu item is clicked. The method must be declared in the activity as public and accept a MenuItem as its only parameter, which indicates the item clicked. This method takes precedence over the standard callback to onOptionsItemSelected().
When and how this item should appear as an action item in the app bar. A menu item can appear as an action item only when the activity includes an app bar

Only place this item in the app bar if there is room for it. If there is not room for all the items marked 'ifRoom', the items with the lowest orderInCategory values are displayed as actions, and the remaining items are displayed in the overflow menu.
Also include the title text (defined by android:title) with the action item. You can include this value along with one of the others as a flag set, by separating them with a pipe |.
Never place this item in the app bar. Instead, list the item in the app bar's overflow menu.

Always place this item in the app bar. Avoid using this unless it's critical that the item always appear in the action bar. Setting multiple items to always appear as action items can result in them overlapping with other UI in the app bar.
The action view associated with this action item (as declared by android:actionLayout or android:actionViewClass) is collapsible.
A layout to use as the action view.
A fully-qualified class name for the View to use as the action view. For example, 'android.widget.SearchView' to use SearchView as an action view.
A fully-qualified class name for the ActionProvider to use in place of the action item. For example, 'android.widget.ShareActionProvider' to use ShareActionProvider
A character for the alphabetic shortcut key.
A number for the numeric shortcut key.
'true' if the item is enabled by default.

Parameter.Name: android:checked
Parameter.Content: 'true' if the item is checked by default.

Description.Content: 'true' if the item is enabled by default.

Parameter.Name: android:visible
Parameter.Content: 'true' if the item is visible by default.

Description.Content: 'true' if the item is enabled by default.
'true' if the item is enabled by default.
Value corresponding to Menu CATEGORY_* constants, which define the item's priority.
For items that are part of a container.
For items that are provided by the system.
For items that are user-supplied secondary (infrequently used) options.
For items that are alternative actions on the data that is currently displayed.
The order of 'importance' of the item, within a group.
A menu group (to create a collection of items that share traits, such as whether they are visible, enabled, or checkable). Contains one or more 'item' elements. Must be a child of a 'menu' element.
A unique resource ID. To create a new resource ID for this item, use the form: '@+id/name'. The plus symbol indicates that this should be created as a new ID.
The type of checkable behavior for the group.
Not checkable.
All items can be checked (use checkboxes).
Only one item can be checked (use radio buttons).
'true' if the group is visible
'true' if the group is enabled
Value corresponding to Menu CATEGORY_* constants, which define the groups's priority.
For groups that are part of a container.
For groups that are provided by the system.
For groups that are user-supplied secondary (infrequently used) options.
For groups that are alternative actions on the data that is currently displayed.
The default order of the items within the category.
